text: <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rekursiv>
I'm skeptical that this would have been any more successful than Intel's failed object-oriented CPU, <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Intel_iAPX_432>

attachments.title: Intel iAPX 432
attachments.text:
The iAPX 432 (Intel Advanced Performance Architecture) was a computer architecture introduced in 1981. It was Intel's first 32-bit processor design. The main processor of the architecture, the general data processor, was implemented as a set of two separate integrated circuits, due to technical limitations at the time. Although some early 8086, 80186 and 80286-based systems and manuals also used the iAPX prefix for marketing reasons, the iAPX 432 and the 8086 processor lines are completely separate designs with completely different instruction sets.
The project started in 1975 as the 8800 (after the 8008 and the 8080) and was intended to be Intel's major design for the 1980s. Unlike the 8086, which was designed the following year as a successor to the 8080, the iAPX 432 was a radical departure from Intel's previous designs meant for a different market niche, and completely unrelated to the 8080 or x86 product lines.
The iAPX 432 project is considered a commercial failure for Intel, and was discontinued in 1986.

elements.text: I'm skeptical that this would have been any more successful than Intel's failed object-oriented CPU,

text: On the other hand, I do agree that there ought to be much better hardware designs out there in design space, if you could start from scratch and not need to design the hardware around the constraints currently imposed by the market.

text:
I've been thinking about this comment for a while.

Definitely agree with the second half. I too push back on Edward here.

But I think you missed my point in the first half. The fact that engineering resources are rarely available should cause us to question if the academic model is sufficient for software research. The constraints are different:

• We don't need much up-front infrastructure. A single person can make progress on projects in off-hours.
• Longitudinal studies are exponentially more valuable than anything else.
• We can't just observe the world. We have to introduce new artifacts into the world and observe how the world reacts and adapts to them over a long period.

So I don't think your statement is a defense of academia at all. I think it's an indictment, narrowly when it comes to computer science academia.
